file.content:
[tool.poetry]
name = "coding-agents-mlops-root"
version = "0.0.0"
description = "Root dev-tooling anchor for the monorepo. Not a publishable package."
authors = []
packages = []

[tool.poetry.group.dev.dependencies]
pytest = "^8.0"
ruff  = "^0.4"

[build-system]
requires      = ["poetry-core"]
build-backend = "poetry.core.masonry.api"

[tool.ruff]
line-length = 100
target-version = "py311"

[tool.ruff.lint]
select = ["E", "F", "I"]

content.thinking:
The environment is running Python 3.14.2, but vllm requires Python `<3.14,>=3.10`. This means the current environment (Python 3.14.2) is too new for vllm.

Let me look at the Makefile and Docker files to understand how the project is set up and where vllm is installed.

content.content:
1→# ── Defaults (override on the command line) ───────────────────────────────────
     2→PROVIDER     ?= anthropic
     3→MODEL        ?= claude-opus-4-6
     4→URL          ?=
     5→JUPYTER_PORT ?= 8888
     6→REGISTRY     ?= docker.io/youruser
     7→K8S_NS       ?= mlops
     8→
     9→# Prepend .venv/bin when it exists (created on macOS by make install).
    10→# All targets that invoke Python tools pick up venv binaries automatically.
    11→VENV_BIN := $(shell [ -d .venv ] && echo "$(PWD)/.venv/bin:" || echo "")
    12→export PATH := $(VENV_BIN)$(PATH)
    13→
    14→.PHONY: help install start stop cli \
    15→        k8s-build k8s-push k8s-secret k8s-deploy k8s-delete k8s-forward k8s-kserve \
    16→        pkg-test
    17→
    18→.DEFAULT_GOAL := help
    19→
    20→# ── help ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    21→help:
    22→	@echo ""
    23→	@echo "Usage:"
    24→	@echo "  make install                       Set up Python, install deps, configure API keys"
    25→	@echo "  make start                         Start Jupyter and MLflow, open in browser"
    26→	@echo "  make stop                          Stop Jupyter and MLflow"
    27→	@echo "  make cli URL=https://...           Generate a Python CLI from a docs URL"
    28→	@echo ""
    29→	@echo "Kubernetes targets (override REGISTRY and K8S_NS as needed):"
    30→	@echo "  make k8s-build                     Build Docker images for jupyter and mlflow"
    31→	@echo "  make k8s-push                      Push images to \$$REGISTRY (default: $(REGISTRY))"
    32→	@echo "  make k8s-secret                    Create mlops-secrets from .env (idempotent)"
    33→	@echo "  make k8s-deploy                    Apply all k8s manifests"
    34→	@echo "  make k8s-delete                    Delete all k8s manifests"
    35→	@echo "  make k8s-forward                   Port-forward jupyter:8888 and mlflow:5000 to localhost"
    36→	@echo "  make k8s-kserve                    Install KServe in Knative serverless mode"
    37→	@echo ""
    38→	@echo "Parameters for make cli (with defaults):"
    39→	@echo "  PROVIDER=$(PROVIDER)   anthropic | huggingface"
    40→	@echo "  MODEL=$(MODEL)"
    41→	@echo "  URL=$(URL)"
    42→	@echo "  JUPYTER_PORT=$(JUPYTER_PORT)"
    43→	@echo ""
    44→	@echo "Monorepo package targets:"
    45→	@echo "  make pkg-test NAME=mypackage           Run tests for one package"
    46→	@echo "  make pkg-test                          Run tests for all packages"
    47→	@echo ""
    48→	@echo "Examples:"
    49→	@echo "  make cli URL=https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages"
    50→	@echo "  make cli URL=https://huggingface.co/docs/hub/api PROVIDER=hf MODEL=mistralai/Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.3"
    51→	@echo "  make k8s-build k8s-push REGISTRY=docker.io/myuser"
    52→	@echo ""
    53→
    54→# ── install ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    55→## Check Python, create venv, install dependencies + Jupyter, create notebooks/,
    56→## and prompt for HuggingFace / Anthropic API keys (skipped when .env exists).
    57→install:
    58→	@chmod +x scripts/setup_jupyter.sh scripts/setup_mlflow.sh scripts/setup_vllm.sh
    59→	@bash scripts/setup_jupyter.sh
    60→	@bash scripts/setup_mlflow.sh
    61→	@bash scripts/setup_vllm.sh
    62→	@echo ""
    63→	@echo "All done. Run 'make start' to launch Jupyter and MLflow."
    64→
    65→# ── start ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    66→## Launch Jupyter and MLflow in the background and open them in your browser.
    67→start:
    68→	@[ -f .env ] || { echo "Run 'make install' first to install dependencies and configure API keys."; exit 1; }
    69→	@mkdir -p notebooks
    70→	@set -a && . ./.env && set +a && \
    71→	  nohup jupyter notebook --port $(JUPYTER_PORT) --notebook-dir notebooks > .jupyter.log 2>&1 & echo $$! > .jupyter.pid
    72→	@echo "Jupyter  : starting on port $(JUPYTER_PORT) … (log: .jupyter.log)"
    73→	@set -a && . ./.env && set +a && \
    74→	  nohup mlflow server --host 127.0.0.1 --port 5000 > .mlflow.log 2>&1 & echo $$! > .mlflow.pid
    75→	@echo "MLflow   : starting at http://127.0.0.1:5000 … (log: .mlflow.log)"
    76→	@sleep 2
    77→	@open http://localhost:$(JUPYTER_PORT) 2>/dev/null || \
    78→	  xdg-open http://localhost:$(JUPYTER_PORT) 2>/dev/null || \
    79→	  echo "Open http://localhost:$(JUPYTER_PORT) in your browser."
    80→	@open http://127.0.0.1:5000 2>/dev/null || \
    81→	  xdg-open http://127.0.0.1:5000 2>/dev/null || true
    82→
    83→# ── stop ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    84→## Stop Jupyter and MLflow servers.
    85→stop:
    86→	@PID=""; \
    87→	[ -f .jupyter.pid ] && PID=$$(cat .jupyter.pid); \
    88→	if [ -n "$$PID" ] && kill "$$PID" 2>/dev/null; then \
    89→	  echo "Jupyter  : stopped (PID $$PID)."; rm -f .jupyter.pid; \
    90→	elif pkill -f "jupyter.*notebook" 2>/dev/null; then \
    91→	  echo "Jupyter  : process killed."; rm -f .jupyter.pid; \
    92→	else \
    93→	  echo "Jupyter  : no server found."; \
    94→	fi
    95→	@PID=""; \
    96→	[ -f .mlflow.pid ] && PID=$$(cat .mlflow.pid); \
    97→	if [ -n "$$PID" ] && kill "$$PID" 2>/dev/null; then \
    98→	  echo "MLflow   : stopped (PID $$PID)."; rm -f .mlflow.pid; \
    99→	elif pkill -f "mlflow.*server" 2>/dev/null; then \
   100→	  echo "MLflow   : process killed."; rm -f .mlflow.pid; \
   101→	else \
   102→	  echo "MLflow   : no server found."; \
   103→	fi
   104→
   105→# ── cli ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   106→## Generate a Python CLI package from a Python SDK documentation URL.
   107→## Usage: make cli URL=https://... [PROVIDER=anthropic|huggingface] [MODEL=model-name]
   108→## Output: cli/<pkg>/ — a fully scaffolded Poetry package saved in the repo.
   109→cli:
   110→	@[ -f .env ] || { echo "Run 'make install' first to install dependencies and configure API keys."; exit 1; }
   111→ifndef URL
   112→	$(error URL is required. Usage: make cli URL=https://... [PROVIDER=anthropic|huggingface] [MODEL=model-name])
   113→endif
   114→	@echo ""
   115→	@echo "Provider : $(PROVIDER)"
   116→	@echo "Model    : $(MODEL)"
   117→	@echo "URL      : $(URL)"
   118→	@echo ""
   119→	@set -a && . ./.env && set +a && \
   120→	  PROVIDER=$(PROVIDER) MODEL=$(MODEL) URL=$(URL) \
   121→	  papermill notebooks/0_generate_cli.ipynb \
   122→	    /tmp/cli_out_$$(date +%s).ipynb \
   123→	    -p PROVIDER "$(PROVIDER)" \
   124→	    -p MODEL    "$(MODEL)" \
   125→	    -p URL      "$(URL)"
   126→
   127→# ── k8s-build ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   128→## Build Docker images for jupyter and mlflow.
   129→k8s-build:
   130→	docker build -t $(REGISTRY)/jupyter:latest -f docker/jupyter/Dockerfile .
   131→	docker build -t $(REGISTRY)/mlflow:latest  -f docker/mlflow/Dockerfile  .
   132→
   133→# ── k8s-push ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   134→## Push images to the container registry.
   135→## Usage: make k8s-push REGISTRY=docker.io/myuser
   136→k8s-push:
   137→	docker push $(REGISTRY)/jupyter:latest
   138→	docker push $(REGISTRY)/mlflow:latest
   139→
   140→# ── k8s-secret ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   141→## Create mlops-secrets in the cluster from the local .env file (idempotent).
   142→k8s-secret:
   143→	@[ -f .env ] || { echo "No .env found. Run 'make install' first."; exit 1; }
   144→	@HF_TOKEN=$$(grep -E '^HF_TOKEN=' .env | cut -d= -f2-) && \
   145→	 ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=$$(grep -E '^ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=' .env | cut -d= -f2-) && \
   146→	 kubectl create secret generic mlops-secrets \
   147→	   --namespace=$(K8S_NS) \
   148→	   --from-literal=HF_TOKEN="$$HF_TOKEN" \
   149→	   --from-literal=ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="$$ANTHROPIC_API_KEY" \
   150→	   --dry-run=client -o yaml | kubectl apply -f -
   151→	@echo "Secret mlops-secrets applied in namespace $(K8S_NS)."
   152→
   153→# ── k8s-deploy ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   154→## Apply all Kubernetes manifests (namespace → configmap → pvcs → deployments → services).
   155→## Substitute REGISTRY into deployment manifests before applying.
   156→k8s-deploy:
   157→	kubectl apply -f k8s/namespace.yaml
   158→	kubectl apply -f k8s/configmap.yaml
   159→	kubectl apply -f k8s/prompts-configmap.yaml
   160→	kubectl apply -f k8s/jupyter/pvc.yaml
   161→	kubectl apply -f k8s/mlflow/pvc.yaml
   162→	REGISTRY=$(REGISTRY) envsubst < k8s/jupyter/deployment.yaml | kubectl apply -f -
   163→	REGISTRY=$(REGISTRY) envsubst < k8s/mlflow/deployment.yaml  | kubectl apply -f -
   164→	kubectl apply -f k8s/jupyter/service.yaml
   165→	kubectl apply -f k8s/mlflow/service.yaml
   166→	@echo "All manifests applied. Check status with: kubectl get pods -n $(K8S_NS)"
   167→
   168→# ── k8s-delete ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   169→## Delete all Kubernetes resources in the mlops namespace.
   170→k8s-delete:
   171→	kubectl delete -f k8s/jupyter/service.yaml    --ignore-not-found
   172→	kubectl delete -f k8s/mlflow/service.yaml     --ignore-not-found
   173→	REGISTRY=$(REGISTRY) envsubst < k8s/jupyter/deployment.yaml | kubectl delete -f - --ignore-not-found
   174→	REGISTRY=$(REGISTRY) envsubst < k8s/mlflow/deployment.yaml  | kubectl delete -f - --ignore-not-found
   175→	kubectl delete -f k8s/jupyter/pvc.yaml        --ignore-not-found
   176→	kubectl delete -f k8s/mlflow/pvc.yaml         --ignore-not-found
   177→	kubectl delete -f k8s/configmap.yaml          --ignore-not-found
   178→	kubectl delete -f k8s/namespace.yaml          --ignore-not-found
   179→
   180→# ── k8s-forward ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   181→## Port-forward jupyter and mlflow to localhost (useful for minikube or headless clusters).
   182→## Press Ctrl-C to stop.
   183→k8s-forward:
   184→	@echo "Forwarding jupyter → http://localhost:8888"
   185→	@echo "Forwarding mlflow  → http://localhost:5000"
   186→	@echo "Press Ctrl-C to stop."
   187→	@kubectl port-forward -n $(K8S_NS) svc/jupyter 8888:8888 &
   188→	@kubectl port-forward -n $(K8S_NS) svc/mlflow  5000:5000 &
   189→	@wait
   190→
   191→# ── k8s-kserve ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   192→## Install KServe in Knative serverless mode.
   193→## Installs: Knative Serving v1.19, Istio 1.28, Cert Manager v1.15, KServe v0.16.
   194→## Requires a running Kubernetes 1.32+ cluster with kubectl configured.
   195→## Uses Helm when available, falls back to YAML.
   196→k8s-kserve:
   197→	@chmod +x scripts/setup_kserve_knative.sh
   198→	@bash scripts/setup_kserve_knative.sh
   199→
   200→# ── pkg-test ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   201→## Run tests for one package or all packages.
   202→## Usage: make pkg-test NAME=mypackage   (single)
   203→##        make pkg-test                  (all)
   204→pkg-test:
   205→ifdef NAME
   206→	@cd "packages/$(NAME)" && poetry install --quiet && poetry run pytest --tb=short -q
   207→else
   208→	@FAILED=""; \
   209→	for dir in packages/*/ cli/*/; do \
   210→	  [ -f "$$dir/pyproject.toml" ] || continue; \
   211→	  echo "── Testing: $$dir"; \
   212→	  (cd "$$dir" && poetry install --quiet && poetry run pytest --tb=short -q) \
   213→	    || FAILED="$$FAILED $$dir"; \
   214→	done; \
   215→	[ -z "$$FAILED" ] && echo "All packages passed." || { echo "FAILED:$$FAILED"; exit 1; }
   216→endif
   217→

file.content:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# vLLM setup for macOS — builds from source, bypassing CUDA requirement.
# Follows: https://medium.com/@rohitkhatana/installing-vllm-on-macos-a-step-by-step-guide-bbbf673461af
set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "$0")" && pwd)"
REPO_ROOT="$(cd "$SCRIPT_DIR/.." && pwd)"

VENDOR_DIR="$REPO_ROOT/vendor"
VLLM_SRC="$VENDOR_DIR/vllm"

# Reuse the project venv when present, otherwise fall back to system pip.
if [ -d "$REPO_ROOT/.venv" ]; then
  PIP_BIN="$REPO_ROOT/.venv/bin/pip"
else
  PIP_BIN="$(command -v pip3 || command -v pip)"
fi

# ── 1. Clone vLLM repository ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
mkdir -p "$VENDOR_DIR"
if [ ! -d "$VLLM_SRC" ]; then
  echo "vllm   : cloning repository …"
  git clone https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm.git "$VLLM_SRC"
  echo "vllm   : cloned"
else
  echo "vllm   : repository already present at vendor/vllm"
fi

# ── 2. Install PyTorch with MPS (Metal Performance Shaders) support ───────────
echo "vllm   : installing PyTorch with MPS support …"
"$PIP_BIN" install torch torchvision --quiet
echo "vllm   : PyTorch installed"

# ── 3. Install vLLM from source, bypassing CUDA requirements ──────────────────
echo "vllm   : building and installing from source (this may take several minutes) …"
export VLLM_TARGET_DEVICE=cpu
export VLLM_BUILD_WITH_CUDA=0
(cd "$VLLM_SRC" && "$PIP_BIN" install -e . --quiet)
echo "vllm   : installed"

file.content:
FROM python:3.11-slim

WORKDIR /home/jovyan

RUN pip install --no-cache-dir notebook papermill

COPY requirements.txt .
RUN pip install --no-cache-dir -r requirements.txt

COPY notebooks/ /home/jovyan/notebooks/

VOLUME ["/home/jovyan/notebooks"]

EXPOSE 8888

CMD ["jupyter", "notebook", \
     "--ip=0.0.0.0", \
     "--port=8888", \
     "--no-browser", \
     "--notebook-dir=/home/jovyan/notebooks", \
     "--NotebookApp.token=''", \
     "--NotebookApp.password=''"]

     "--host", "0.0.0.0", \

     "--default-artifact-root", "/mlflow/artifacts"]

content.thinking:
Now I understand the problem. The project has a local `.venv` with Python 3.14.2, but vllm requires Python `<3.14,>=3.10`. 

The `setup_vllm.sh` script tries to install vllm from source by cloning the repository and installing it. However, the problem is that the vllm repository's `setup.py` or `pyproject.toml` specifies `python_requires=">=3.10,<3.14"`, so it fails when using Python 3.14.2.

Since vllm doesn't support Python 3.14 yet, the options are:


1. Skip vllm installation on Python 3.14 (since it's not compatible)
2. Make the vllm setup script more resilient - print a warning and continue instead of failing
3. If vllm is used somewhere in the project, note that it won't work with Python 3.14

Looking at the Makefile, the `install` target calls `setup_vllm.sh`, and the script uses `set -e` which means any failure exits immediately. The best approach would be to update `setup_vllm.sh` to check the Python version first and either skip the installation or handle the failure gracefully with a warning instead of crashing the entire setup.

Now I'm checking if vllm is referenced anywhere else in the codebase beyond the setup script.

content.text:
Now I understand the issue. The `.venv` uses Python 3.14.2, but vllm's `python_requires` constraint is `>=3.10,<3.14`. The `setup_vllm.sh` script runs with `set -e`, so this error aborts `make install`.

Let me check if vllm is referenced elsewhere:

input.description: Check Python version and venv Python

content.thinking:
vllm is only referenced in `scripts/setup_vllm.sh` and nowhere else in the codebase. The fix should be in `setup_vllm.sh` - we need to add a Python version check at the beginning of the script. If Python >= 3.14 is detected, we should print a warning and skip the installation gracefully (instead of failing with `set -e`).

Actually, looking at this more carefully - the script clones from source and installs with `pip install -e .`. The problem is vllm's own `pyproject.toml` or `setup.py` has the `python_requires=">=3.10,<3.14"` constraint, which pip enforces.


So I'll add a Python version check at the start of `setup_vllm.sh` that detects if we're running Python 3.14 or higher, prints a warning about the incompatibility, and exits cleanly with code 0 to skip the installation without triggering the `set -e` failure.

content.text: vllm is only used in `setup_vllm.sh`. Since vllm doesn't support Python 3.14 yet, the fix is to add a version check to the script and skip gracefully instead of aborting `make install`.

input.new_string:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# vLLM setup for macOS — builds from source, bypassing CUDA requirement.
# Follows: https://medium.com/@rohitkhatana/installing-vllm-on-macos-a-step-by-step-guide-bbbf673461af
set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "$0")" && pwd)"
REPO_ROOT="$(cd "$SCRIPT_DIR/.." && pwd)"

# Reuse the project venv python when present, otherwise fall back to system python3.
if [ -d "$REPO_ROOT/.venv" ]; then
  PYTHON_BIN="$REPO_ROOT/.venv/bin/python"
else
  PYTHON_BIN="$(command -v python3 || command -v python)"
fi

# vLLM requires Python >=3.10,<3.14. Skip gracefully on unsupported versions.
PY_MAJOR=$("$PYTHON_BIN" -c "import sys; print(sys.version_info.major)")
PY_MINOR=$("$PYTHON_BIN" -c "import sys; print(sys.version_info.minor)")
if [ "$PY_MAJOR" -gt 3 ] || { [ "$PY_MAJOR" -eq 3 ] && [ "$PY_MINOR" -ge 14 ]; }; then
  echo "vllm   : skipped — vLLM requires Python >=3.10,<3.14 (found ${PY_MAJOR}.${PY_MINOR})"
  exit 0
fi

toolUseResult.originalFile:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# vLLM setup for macOS — builds from source, bypassing CUDA requirement.
# Follows: https://medium.com/@rohitkhatana/installing-vllm-on-macos-a-step-by-step-guide-bbbf673461af
set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "$0")" && pwd)"
REPO_ROOT="$(cd "$SCRIPT_DIR/.." && pwd)"

VENDOR_DIR="$REPO_ROOT/vendor"
VLLM_SRC="$VENDOR_DIR/vllm"

# Reuse the project venv when present, otherwise fall back to system pip.
if [ -d "$REPO_ROOT/.venv" ]; then
  PIP_BIN="$REPO_ROOT/.venv/bin/pip"
else
  PIP_BIN="$(command -v pip3 || command -v pip)"
fi

# ── 1. Clone vLLM repository ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
mkdir -p "$VENDOR_DIR"
if [ ! -d "$VLLM_SRC" ]; then
  echo "vllm   : cloning repository …"
  git clone https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm.git "$VLLM_SRC"
  echo "vllm   : cloned"
else
  echo "vllm   : repository already present at vendor/vllm"
fi

# ── 2. Install PyTorch with MPS (Metal Performance Shaders) support ───────────
echo "vllm   : installing PyTorch with MPS support …"
"$PIP_BIN" install torch torchvision --quiet
echo "vllm   : PyTorch installed"

# ── 3. Install vLLM from source, bypassing CUDA requirements ──────────────────
echo "vllm   : building and installing from source (this may take several minutes) …"
export VLLM_TARGET_DEVICE=cpu
export VLLM_BUILD_WITH_CUDA=0
(cd "$VLLM_SRC" && "$PIP_BIN" install -e . --quiet)
echo "vllm   : installed"

lines: +# Reuse the project venv python when present, otherwise fall back to system python3.
+# vLLM requires Python >=3.10,<3.14. Skip gracefully on unsupported versions.

content.text: Now fix the duplicate `PIP_BIN` / Python detection — the original script also derives `PIP_BIN` from the venv, but we can reuse the already-detected path:

    28→if [ -d "$REPO_ROOT/.venv" ]; then
    29→  PIP_BIN="$REPO_ROOT/.venv/bin/pip"
    30→else
    31→  PIP_BIN="$(command -v pip3 || command -v pip)"
    32→fi
    33→
    34→# ── 1. Clone vLLM repository ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
    35→mkdir -p "$VENDOR_DIR"
    36→if [ ! -d "$VLLM_SRC" ]; then
    37→  echo "vllm   : cloning repository …"
    38→  git clone https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm.git "$VLLM_SRC"
    39→  echo "vllm   : cloned"
    40→else
    41→  echo "vllm   : repository already present at vendor/vllm"
    42→fi
    43→
    44→# ── 2. Install PyTorch with MPS (Metal Performance Shaders) support ───────────
    45→echo "vllm   : installing PyTorch with MPS support …"
    46→"$PIP_BIN" install torch torchvision --quiet
    47→echo "vllm   : PyTorch installed"
    48→
    49→# ── 3. Install vLLM from source, bypassing CUDA requirements ──────────────────
    50→echo "vllm   : building and installing from source (this may take several minutes) …"
    51→export VLLM_TARGET_DEVICE=cpu
    52→export VLLM_BUILD_WITH_CUDA=0
    53→(cd "$VLLM_SRC" && "$PIP_BIN" install -e . --quiet)
    54→echo "vllm   : installed"
    55→

file.content:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# vLLM setup for macOS — builds from source, bypassing CUDA requirement.
# Follows: https://medium.com/@rohitkhatana/installing-vllm-on-macos-a-step-by-step-guide-bbbf673461af
set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "$0")" && pwd)"
REPO_ROOT="$(cd "$SCRIPT_DIR/.." && pwd)"

# Reuse the project venv python when present, otherwise fall back to system python3.
if [ -d "$REPO_ROOT/.venv" ]; then
  PYTHON_BIN="$REPO_ROOT/.venv/bin/python"
else
  PYTHON_BIN="$(command -v python3 || command -v python)"
fi

# vLLM requires Python >=3.10,<3.14. Skip gracefully on unsupported versions.
PY_MAJOR=$("$PYTHON_BIN" -c "import sys; print(sys.version_info.major)")
PY_MINOR=$("$PYTHON_BIN" -c "import sys; print(sys.version_info.minor)")
if [ "$PY_MAJOR" -gt 3 ] || { [ "$PY_MAJOR" -eq 3 ] && [ "$PY_MINOR" -ge 14 ]; }; then
  echo "vllm   : skipped — vLLM requires Python >=3.10,<3.14 (found ${PY_MAJOR}.${PY_MINOR})"
  exit 0
fi

VENDOR_DIR="$REPO_ROOT/vendor"
VLLM_SRC="$VENDOR_DIR/vllm"

# Reuse the project venv when present, otherwise fall back to system pip.
if [ -d "$REPO_ROOT/.venv" ]; then
  PIP_BIN="$REPO_ROOT/.venv/bin/pip"
else
  PIP_BIN="$(command -v pip3 || command -v pip)"
fi

# ── 1. Clone vLLM repository ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
mkdir -p "$VENDOR_DIR"
if [ ! -d "$VLLM_SRC" ]; then
  echo "vllm   : cloning repository …"
  git clone https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm.git "$VLLM_SRC"
  echo "vllm   : cloned"
else
  echo "vllm   : repository already present at vendor/vllm"
fi

# ── 2. Install PyTorch with MPS (Metal Performance Shaders) support ───────────
echo "vllm   : installing PyTorch with MPS support …"
"$PIP_BIN" install torch torchvision --quiet
echo "vllm   : PyTorch installed"

# ── 3. Install vLLM from source, bypassing CUDA requirements ──────────────────
echo "vllm   : building and installing from source (this may take several minutes) …"
export VLLM_TARGET_DEVICE=cpu
export VLLM_BUILD_WITH_CUDA=0
(cd "$VLLM_SRC" && "$PIP_BIN" install -e . --quiet)
echo "vllm   : installed"

content.text: The file looks good. The version check is added before any vllm work happens. Let me verify the logic works correctly:

input.description: Check bash syntax of the script

content.text:
The fix is in place. Here's what was changed and why:

**Problem:** `scripts/setup_vllm.sh` runs `set -e` and tries to `pip install` vllm from source. vllm's own `pyproject.toml` declares `python_requires=">=3.10,<3.14"`, so pip rejects the install on Python 3.14.2, causing `make install` to abort.

**Fix:** Added a Python version guard at the top of `setup_vllm.sh` (lines 9–22). It detects the active Python version and exits with code `0` (skip, not failure) when Python ≥ 3.14 is found, printing a clear message:

```
vllm   : skipped — vLLM requires Python >=3.10,<3.14 (found 3.14)
```

This lets `make install` complete successfully. When vllm adds Python 3.14 support, the check will naturally stop triggering and the install will proceed normally.
